Answers.Text: Select a higher gear than normal
Signal so that other drivers can slow down
Look over your shoulder for final confirmation
Give another signal as well as using your indicators

Text: Before making a U - turn in the road  you should always:

Answers.Text: An area covered by your left hand mirror
An area not covered by your headlights
An area covered by your right hand mirror
An area not covered by your mirrors

Text: As a driver what do you understand by the term 'Blind Spot'?
What does the abbreviation MSM mean?

Answers.Text: It helps you to keep out of the wind
It helps the large vehicle to stop more easily
It allows the driver to see you in the mirror
It allows you to corner more quickly

Text: When following a large vehicle you should stay well back because

Answers.Text: Approaching a dip in the road

Text: In which of these following situations should you avoid overtaking?

Answers.Text: Because reception is poor when the engine is running
Unless you are able to drive one handed
Because it might distract your attention from the road ahead
Until you are satisfied that no other traffic is near

Text: You should not use a mobile phone whilst driving

Answers.Text: Could be very good for road safety
Could distract your attention from the road
Is recommended by The Highway Code
Is quite safe as long as you slow down

Text: Your vehicle is fitted with a hands- free phone system. Using this equipment whilst driving
Using a hands-free phone is likely to

Answers.Text: Will reduce your field of vision
Could distract your attention from the road
Is acceptable in a vehicle with power steering

Text: Using a mobile phone while you are driving

Answers.Text: Quickly  sounding the horn as you pass
Slowly  sounding the horn as you pass

Text: You are driving along a narrow country road. When passing a cyclist you should drive

Answers.Text: Slow down and allow others to overtake
Stop in a proper and convenient place
Keep the call time to a minimum
Reduce your speed wherever you are

Text: To answer your mobile phone when driving  you should:

Answers.Text: Because the car electrics will be affected
So that the control of your vehicle is not affected
So that a proper conversation can be held
Because the reception is better when stopped

Text: Why should you be parked before using a mobile phone?
You are driving in the dark and are dazzled by the headlights of an oncoming car.You should

Answers.Text: So that others can see you
Even when street lights are lit
Only when street lights are lit
Only when others have done so

Text: You are driving at dusk. Your lights should be switched on

Answers.Text: Check the speed and position of following traffic
Get in close behind before moving out
Cut back in sharply when you have passed the vehicle

Text: To overtake safely  which one of the following applies?
A pelican crossing that crosses the road in a STRAIGHT line and has a central traffic island MUST be treated as:

Answers.Text: Give way to pedestrians already on the crossing
Stop and wait for the red light
Give way to pedestrians waiting to cross
Stop and wait for the green lights

Text: When at a pelican crossing the amber light means you MUST

Answers.Text: Not move until the green light appears
Stop and wait for the red light even if the crossing is clear

Text: You are approaching a pelican crossing. The amber light is showing. You MUST:

Answers.Text: Wave at them to cross the road
Slow down and prepare to stop
Use your headlights to indicate they can cross
Give way to elderly and infirm only

Text: You are approaching a zebra crossing. Pedestrians are waiting to cross. You should:
You have stopped at a pedestrian (zebra) crossing to allow pedestrians to cross. You should:

Answers.Text: There may be another vehicle coming
They may not be ready to cross
It is safer for you to carry on

Text: You should never wave or urge people across at a pedestrian crossing because:

Answers.Text: Wave pedestrians to cross if you intend to wait for them to
Park only on the zigzag lines on the left
Always leave it clear in traffic queues
Rev your engine to encourage pedestrians to cross quickly

Text: At a Pedestrian (zebra) crossing you should:
You stopped for pedestrians waiting to cross at a zebra crossing. They did not start to cross. What should you do?

Answers.Text: To keep a safe gap from the vehicle in front
Before using the 'Mirror - Signal - manoeuvre' routine
Before restarting the engine after it has stalled

Text: You may use the 'Two-Second Rule'

Answers.Text: Drive with rear fog lights off
Look through the rear view mirror

Text: When following another vehicle whilst driving on the road you should not

Answers.Text: The driver cannot see you in his mirrors

Text: Following this vehicle too closely is unwise because:
You are following a vehicle on a wet and slippery road. You should leave a time gap of at least

Answers.Text: Move over to a position just left of the centre line of the road
Slow down  gradually increasing the gap between you and the vehicle in front
Signal left and wave the following driver past
Ignore the following driver and continue to drive within the speed limit

Text: You are in a line of traffic. The driver behind you is following very closely. What action should you take?

Answers.Text: Maintain your speed to prevent the vehicle from overtaking
Touch the brakes to show your brake lights
Accelerate to make a gap behind you

Text: You are driving at the legal speed limit. A vehicle comes up quickly behind  flashingits headlights. You should:
When are you permitted to exceed the maximum speed limit?
A heavy lorry is taking a long time to overtake you. What should you do?
Which of the following cars will use blue flashing beacons?

Answers.Text: Pull over as soon as safely possible to let it pass
Brake harshly and immediately stop in the road
Accelerate fast to get away from it

Text: When being followed by an ambulance showing a flashing blue light you should:

Answers.Text: Slow down and then sound your horn
Slow down and give way if it is safe to do so
Sound your horn and keep going
Flash your headlights and slow down

Text: A bus has stopped at a bus stop ahead of you. Its right-hand indicator is flashing. You should

Answers.Text: To tell them that you have right of way
To show that you are about to reverse
To show that you are giving way
To let them know that you are there

Text: You should ONLY flash your headlights to other roads users:

Answers.Text: To alert others of your presence
To allow you right of way

Text: Why should you use your horn?

Answers.Text: Just left of the centre line
In either lane  depending on the traffic
As close as you safely can to the right hand side of the street

Text: You are in a one-way street and want to turn right. You should place yourself

Answers.Text: To allow drivers to pass you on the right
To give a better view into the road that you're joining
To help other road users know what you intend to do
To allow other drivers to pull out in front of you

Text: You wish to turn right ahead. Why should you take up the proper position in goodtime?

Answers.Text: After checking it is safe to do so, before changing course or direction, turning to the left or right, stopping or moving
Only when joining a dual carriageway from a slip road so you don't have to give way.
At all times in order to alert other road users  including pedestrians  of your intended actions.
In traffic only during the hours of darkness or in bad weather.
To give you priority over other traffic when changing lanes or before pulling out.

Text: When should you give signals?
Which of these fluids, if allowed to get low, is dangerous?
Which TWO are adversely affected if the tyres are under-inflated?
It is important that tyre pressure is regularly checked. When should this be done?

Answers.Text: Every time the vehicle has an VRT test
Every time the vehicle is serviced

Text: It is very important that tyre pressures are correct. They should be checked at least:
Driving with under-inflated (low) tyres can affect:
When MUST you use dipped lights during the day?
How can you  as a vehicle driver help the environment?
Motor vehicles can harm the environment resulting in:
To reduce the damage your vehicle causes to the environment you should:

Answers.Text: Walk or cycle when you can

Text: You will help your environment if you:

Answers.Text: Empty the boot of unnecessary weight
Use your vehicle for very short journeys
Walk  cycle  or use public transport
Remove your roof rack when unloaded

Text: To help the environment you should NOT:
Excessive or uneven wear on the tyres can be caused by faults in:

Answers.Text: Short journeys with a cold engine

Text: Which of the following will reduce fuel consumption?

Answers.Text: Between 11.30 pm and 7 am in a built-up area
At any time in a built-up area
Between 10 pm and 6 am in a built-up area
Between 11.00 pm and 6 am in a built-up area

Text: You should NOT sound your horn:
In some residential roads you will find a speed limit of:
Road humps, chicanes and narrowing are:

Answers.Text: Drive slowly at school times only
Always keep to the maximum legal speed

Text: You enter a road where there are road humps. You should:
If you are on a good dry road surface and your vehicle has good brakes and tyres. What is the overall stopping distance at 48 kph?
Braking hard at a high speed on a sharp bend can make your vehicle:

Answers.Text: Keep close to the car in front
Allow more time for your journey

Text: When driving in fog  which of the following measures are correct?

Answers.Text: Keep a safe distance from the car in front
Keep the correct distance from the kerb

Text: The 'two-second rule' allows you to:
Your overall stopping distance will be longer when driving:

Answers.Text: Steer towards the side of the road

Text: You are driving in heavy rain. Your steering suddenly becomes very light. You should:
The MAIN cause of skidding is:

Answers.Text: Be ready to move off quickly
Creep forward  looking to the left
Creep forward  looking to the right

Text: If you are at a junction with limited visibility  you should:
In very hot weather the road surface can get soft. Which TWO of the following will be affected most?

Answers.Text: Turn as quickly as you can
Give an arm signal as well as using your indicator
Touch the brake several times to show the stop lamp(s)

Text: Your indicators may be difficult to see in bright sunlight. What should you do?

Answers.Text: By changing to a higher gear
By changing to a lower gear

Text: How can you use the engine of your vehicle as a brake?

Answers.Text: Wait for any pedestrians to cross
Move across to the left-hand side of the road

Text: You are driving in a built-up residential area. You are approaching road humps. You should:

Answers.Text: To be positioned safely if the vehicle skids
To let faster traffic from behind overtake
To overcome the effect of the road's slope
To improve your view of the road

Text: When approaching a right-hand bend you should keep well to the left. Why is this?

Answers.Text: Keep well to the right to make the bend less sharp
Keep well to the left for a better view around the bend
Keep well to the right to avoid anything in the gutter
Keep well to the left as it makes the bend faster

Text: You are approaching a right-hand bend. You should:

Answers.Text: Intending to turn left shortly afterwards

Text: You should not overtake when:
A driver can only read a number plate at the required distance with glasses on. The glasses should be worn:

Answers.Text: Borrow a friend's glasses and drive home
Drive home slowly  keeping to quite roads
Find a way of getting home without driving

Text: You are about to drive home. You cannot find the glasses you need to wear when driving. You should:

Answers.Text: There is an eyesight problem in your family
You cannot read a vehicle number plate from a distance of 36 meters (120 feet) without them
You are the holder of an orange badge
You cannot read a vehicle number plate from distance of 20.5 meters (67 feet) without them

Text: You MUST wear glasses or contact lenses when driving on public roads if:
Which THREE result from drinking alcohol and driving?
Which THREE of these are likely effects of drinking alcohol on driving?

Answers.Text: Give a false sense of confidence
Increase the speed of your reactions
Slow down your reactions to hazards

Text: Drinking any amount of alcohol is likely to:

Answers.Text: Eat a hot meal with your alcohol drinks
Have some milk before drinking alcohol
Not drink any alcohol at all

Text: You are invited to a pub lunch. You know that you will have to drive in the evening. What is your best course of action?
What else can seriously affect your concentration when driving  other than alcoholic drinks?
How does alcohol affect your driving?

Answers.Text: Your concentration may still be badly affected
You may still be over the legal limit
You will be well under the legal limit
Your concentration will not be badly affected

Text: After drinking alcohol heavily you should not drive the following day. Why is this?

Answers.Text: Wait a short while and then drive home
Have a strong cup of coffee and then drive home

Text: What advice should you give to a driver who has had a few alcoholic drinks at a party?

Answers.Text: Drink plenty of milk before drinking alcohol
Drink plenty of coffee after drinking alcohol
Avoid drinking alcohol on an empty stomach

Text: You go to a social event and need to drive a short time after. What precautions should you take?

Answers.Text: You will have no alcohol in your system
You will certainly be under the legal limit
You may still be unfit to drive
You may still be over the legal limit

Text: It is eight hours since you last had an alcoholic drink. Which TWO of the following applies?

Answers.Text: The medicine you take may affect your hearing
You will have to let your insurance company know about the medicine
Some types of medicine can cause your reactions to slow down
Drugs make you a better driver by quickening your reactions

Text: Your doctor has given you a course of medicine. Why should you ask if it is OK to drive?

You have been taking medicine for a few days  which made you feel drowsy. Today you feel better but still need to take the medicine. You
should only drive:

Answers.Text: Never drive at more than 30 kph
Drive only if someone is with you

Text: You become ill. A doctor prescribes drugs  which are likely to affect your driving. You should:

Answers.Text: Take all your medicines with you when you drive
Only take smaller doses of any medicines
Not drive after taking certain medicines
See your doctor each time before you drive

Text: During periods of illness your ability to drive may be impaired. You MUST:

Answers.Text: Only drive if accompanied by a full licence-holder
Limit your driving to essential journeys

Text: You are taking drugs that are likely to affect your driving. What should you do?

Answers.Text: Keep changing speed to improve concentration
Increase your speed to find a stopping place quickly
Ensure a supply of fresh air

Text: If you are feeling tired it is best to stop as soon as you can. Until then you should:
Your reaction will be much slower when driving:
Which THREE are likely to make you lose concentration while driving?

Answers.Text: Ignore the error and stay calm
Sound your horn to show your annoyance
Flash your lights to show your annoyance

Text: A driver pulls out of a side road in front of you. You have to brake hard. You should

Answers.Text: Flag the driver down and explain the mistake
Drive close behind and sound your horn

Text: A car driver pulls out causing you to brake. You should:

Answers.Text: Let them know how you feel

Text: Another driver does something that upsets you. You should:
An elderly person's driving ability could be affected because they may be unable to:

Answers.Text: Turn around and drive against the one-way
Continue to the end of the one-way street

Text: You take the wrong route and find you are well into a one-way street. You should:

Answers.Text: Breath alcohol level of 20 mg/100ml or blood alcohol level of 60mm/100ml.
Breath alcohol level of 35 mg/100ml or blood alcohol level of 80mg/100ml.
Breath alcohol level of 45 mg/100ml or blood alcohol level of 90mm/100ml.
Breath alcohol level of 25 mg/100ml or blood alcohol level of 70mg/100ml.

Text: What is the maximum permissible alcohol level above which  a driver must not drive?
You are driving on a quiet country road. What should you expect to see coming towards you on YOUR side of the road?
Which sign means that there may be people walking along the road?
You are turning left into a side road and find pedestrians that are crossing. You must:

Answers.Text: Stop and wave at them to cross
Go on giving them plenty of room

Text: You are turning left at a junction. Pedestrians have suddenly started to cross the road. You should:

Answers.Text: Stop  get out and look along the main road to check
Sound your horn and pull out if there is no reply
Move out quickly  but be prepared to stop
Stop  then move slowly forward until you have a clear view

Text: You want to emerge from a junction but your view is partly restricted by parked vehicles. What should you do?

Answers.Text: To make sure the side road is clear
To look for pedestrians about to cross

Text:
You are at the front of a queue of traffic waiting to turn right into a side road. Why is it important to check your right mirror just before
turning?

Answers.Text: Always wait for the green light before proceeding
Give way to any pedestrians on the crossing

Text: What should a driver do at a pelican crossing when the red and amber lights are on?

Answers.Text: Drive in front of the person

Text:
You have stopped at a pelican crossing. A disabled person is crossing slowly in front of you.The lights have now changed to green.
You should:

Answers.Text: Flash your lights in case they have not heard you
Rev your engine to make them hurry
Wave them to cross as quickly as they can
Wait because they will take longer to cross

Text: As you approach a pelican crossing the lights change to green but elderly people are halfway across. You should:

Answers.Text: The car on the left may move off
The driver of the ice cream van may get out
The ice cream van may move off
The child may run out into the road

Text: Look at this picture. What is the danger you should be most aware of?

Answers.Text: Brake sharply and flash your headlights
Slow down and wave the cyclist across
Accelerate past quickly and sound your horn
Slow down and be prepared to stop for a cyclist

Text: You are driving past parked cars. You notice a wheel of a bicycle sticking out between them. What should you do?

Answers.Text: Stop and wave the children across to fetch their ball
Continue driving at the same speed and flash your headlights
Slow down and be prepared to stop for children
Continue driving at the same speed and sound your horn

Text: You are driving past a lane of parked cars and you notice a ball bouncing out into the road ahead. What should you do?

Answers.Text: Stay close behind and drive carefully
Be aware that the driver's reactions may not be as fast as yours
Expect the driver to drive badly

Text: If you are following a car driven by an elderly driver  you should:
Which sign tells you that pedestrians may be walking in the road  as there is no pavement?
Which sign means there maybe elderly pedestrians likely to cross the road?
If you see a pedestrian carrying a white stick, this shows that the person is:

Answers.Text: Wave to the person to wait
Wave to the person to cross

Text: You are driving towards a pedestrian (zebra) crossing. Waiting to cross is a person in a wheelchair. You should:

Answers.Text: Tap the horn in case they are hard of hearing
Be patient and allow them to cross in their own time
Rev the engine to let them know that you are waiting
Wave them across so they know that you have seen them

Text: What action should you take when elderly people are crossing the road?
You should NEVER attempt to overtake a cyclist:

Answers.Text: Go around the cyclist on the junction
Pull alongside the cyclist and stay level until after the junction
Hold back until the cyclist has passed the junction
Overtake the cyclist before the junction

Text: If you are driving behind a cyclist and you wish to turn left just ahead. You should:

Answers.Text: Signal the cyclist to move across
Give the cyclist plenty of room

Text: You are coming up to a roundabout and a cyclist is signaling to turn right. What should you do:

You are driving behind three cyclists. They approach a roundabout in the left-hand lane. In which direction should you
expect the cyclists to go?

Answers.Text: The cyclist thinks The highway Code does not apply to
The cyclist is going to turn left instead
It is quicker route for cyclist
The cyclist is slower and more vulnerable

Text: You are approaching a roundabout and see a cyclist signal right. Why is the cyclist keeping to the left?

Answers.Text: The cyclist might have to make a right turn
The cyclist might get off the bike

Text:
When you are overtaking a cyclist in the road you should leave as much room as you would give to a car. What is the main reason for
this?
Where should you take particular care to look out for motorcyclists and cyclists?

Answers.Text: So that the rider can be seen more easily
The rider is inviting you to proceed

Text: In daylight  an approaching motorcyclist is using a dipped headlight. Why?

Answers.Text: Sound your horn as a warning and pull in front of the moped
Pull alongside the moped and stay level until just before the junction
Overtake the moped before the junction
Stay behind until the moped has passed the junction

Text: You are driving behind a moped or a small motorcycle. You want to turn left just ahead. You should:
At road junctions which THREE of the following are most vulnerable?
When emerging from a side road into a queue of traffic which road users can be difficult to see?

Answers.Text: Check for traffic overtaking on your right

Text: You want to turn right from a main road into a side road. Just before you turn you should:
You are driving and ahead of you there is a vehicle with a flashing amber beacon.This means it is:

Answers.Text: Move the person off the road

Text: An injured motorcyclist is lying unconscious in the road. You should:

Answers.Text: The bus may move off suddenly
The bus may have broken down
Pedestrians may come from behind the bus

Text: You are driving in town. There is a bus at the bus stop on the other side of the road. Why should you be careful?

Answers.Text: Use your horn just once to warn them
Speed is not important but allow plenty of room
Drive along their side and overtake as soon as possible
Drive slowly and leave plenty of room

Text: How should you overtake horse riders?

Answers.Text: Pull out to the middle of the road

Text: You notice horse riders ahead of you. What should you do FIRST?
You are driving on a narrow country road. Where would you find it most difficult to see horses and riders ahead of you?
A horse rider is in the left-hand lane approaching a roundabout. The driver behind should expect the rider to:

Answers.Text: Sound your horn as a warning
Accelerate past as quickly as possible
Treat them like any other vehicle

Text: You are approaching a roundabout. There are horses just ahead of you. You should:

You see a group of horse riders as you approach a roundabout. They are signalling to go right but keeping well to the left. You
should:
What is the MOST common cause of road accidents?
Which age group is most likely to be involved in traffic accidents?

Answers.Text: Be patient as you expect them to make mistakes
Immediately steer around them and drive on
Start to rev your engine if they take too long to restart
Drive up close behind and flash your headlights

Text: You are following a learner driver who stalls at a junction. What should you do?

Answers.Text: The large vehicle can easily hide vehicles from the left
The large vehicle is difficult to steer in a straight line
The large vehicle can turn suddenly
The large vehicle can easily hide an overtaking vehicle

Text:
You are waiting to emerge left from a minor road. A large vehicle is approaching from the right. You have time to turn, but you should
wait. Why?

Answers.Text: Overtake quickly before the lorry moves out
Pass on the left as the vehicle moves out
Be prepared to stop behind it
Move out and overtake on the offside

Text: You are driving behind a large articulated vehicle (trailer). It is going to turn left into a narrow road. What action should you take?

Answers.Text: Overtake as it starts to slow down
Stay well back and give it room
Assume the signal is wrong and it is really turning right
Get closer in order to pass it quickly

Text: You are driving behind a long vehicle. It approaches a crossroads and signals left, but moves out to the right. You should:

Answers.Text: Report the driver to the police
Warn the driver of the wrong signal

Text:
You are driving behind a long vehicle approaching a crossroad. The driver signals right but moves close to the left-hand kerb. What
should you do?

Answers.Text: Follow the same course as the lorry

Text:
You are approaching a small roundabout. The long vehicle in front is signaling left but is positioned over to the right. You
should:
You keep well back while waiting to overtake a large lorry. Another car fills the gap. You should:

Answers.Text: To offer other drivers a safe gap if they want to overtake you
To get the best view of the road ahead
To leave a gap in case it stops and rolls back
To give acceleration space to overtake quickly on blind bends

Text: Before overtaking a large vehicle or lorry you should keep well back. Why is this?

Answers.Text: Stay behind until the driver waves you past
Flash your headlights for the oncoming traffic to give way
Follow it closely and keep moving out to see the road ahead
Keep well back until you can see that it is clear

Text: You wish to overtake a long, slow moving vehicle or lorry on a busy road with oncoming traffic. You should:

Answers.Text: Pull over on the right behind the parked car
Speed up and get past quickly
Keep going because you have the right of way

Text:
You are driving downhill. There is a car parked on the other side of the road partly blocking the road. Large, slow lorries are coming
towards you. You should:

Answers.Text: Flash your lights and wait for the driver to signal when it is
Stay well back from the lorry to obtain a better view
Drive close to the lorry in order to pass more quickly
Sound the horn to warn the driver that you are there

Text: When about to overtake a long vehicle or lorry you should:

Answers.Text: Be ready to give way to the bus
Pull in closely behind the bus
Accelerate past the bus sounding your horn

Text: You are traveling behind a bus that suddenly pulls up at a bus stop. What should you do?

Answers.Text: Be prepared to give way if the bus suddenly moves off
Continue at the same speed but sound your horn as warning
Watch carefully for the sudden appearance of pedestrians
Pass the bus as quickly as you possibly can

Text: You are driving in a city. Ahead of you a bus is at a bus stop. Which TWO of the following should you do?

Answers.Text: Signal left and wave the bus on
Allow it to pull away,  if it is safe to do so
Flash your headlights as you approach

Text: When you approach a bus that is about to move off from a bus stop you should:

Answers.Text: When stationary vehicles are too close in a queue
When a vehicle is with its back doors open
When a vehicle delivering goods has its tailgate down
When a driver is following another vehicle too closely

Text: What is the effect of not keeping to the two second rule 'tailgating' when driving on a dry and good road surface?

Answers.Text: Drop back until you can see better
Keep close to the lorry  away from the spray
Put your headlights on full beam

Text: You are following a large lorry on a wet road. Spray makes it difficult to see. You should:
You are driving on a dual- carriageway with surface spray. You should use:

Answers.Text: You have less braking and steering control
It puts more wear and tear on the tyres
The vehicle will pick up speed

Text: What are TWO main reasons why coasting downhill is dangerous or wrong?

Answers.Text: It will make the engine stall
It will cause the car to skid

Text: Why is coasting wrong or dangerous?
Hills can affect the performance of your vehicle. Which TWO apply when driving up steep hills?
You are approaching a bend at a high speed. You should begin to brake.

Answers.Text: Stay close to the other vehicle until it moves on
Try to overtake safely as soon as you can
Drop back to regain a safe distance
Flash your headlights as a warning

Text:
You are following a vehicle at a safe distance on a wet and slippery road. Another driver overtakes you and pulls into the gap you have
left. What should you do?

Answers.Text: When the vehicle in front is to turn right
When a slower vehicle is in the right-hand lane of a dual carriageway
When you are in a one-way street
In slow-moving traffic queues when traffic in the right-hand lane is moving more slowly

Text: In which THREE of these situations may you overtake another vehicle on the inside, or the left?
Which THREE of the following will affect your stopping distance?
You are in a very heavy downpour. Your overall stopping distance is likely to be:

Answers.Text: Keep two seconds behind other vehicles
Never use demisters and windscreens wipers.
Leave plenty of time for your journey
Follow closely other vehicle's tail lights

Text: You have to make a journey in foggy conditions. You should:

Answers.Text: Keep together with the faster vehicles
Use your main beam instead of dipped headlights
Keep close to the vehicle in front
Reduce your speed and increase the gap

Text: You are following other vehicles in fog with your lights on. How else can you reduce the chances of being involved in an accident?

Answers.Text: Because you could be dazzled by other people's fog lights
Because the brakes do not work as well
Because it is more difficult to see events ahead

Text: Why should you always reduce your speed when driving in fog?

Answers.Text: In case its brake lights dazzle you
In case its fog lights dazzle you
In case it changes direction suddenly

Text: You are driving in fog. Why should you keep well back from the vehicle in front?

Answers.Text: Be useful when towing a trailer

Text: Using rear fog lights in clear daylight or tunnels will:

Answers.Text: Wait until a bend so that you can see the oncoming
Beware of the bends in the road ahead
Sound your horn twice before moving out
Be careful because you can see less

Text: Which TWO of the following are correct? When overtaking at night you should:

Answers.Text: Your rear fog lights are switched on
You have switched your lights to full beam before overtaking
You flash your headlamps before overtaking
You do not dazzle other road users

Text: You are overtaking a car at night. You must be sure that:

Answers.Text: Put your hand over your eyes
Switch on your main beam headlights

Text: At night  you are dazzled by headlights of vehicles coming towards you. You should:

Answers.Text: Drive faster past the oncoming car

Text: You are dazzled by headlights of oncoming vehicles when driving at night. What should you do?

Answers.Text: Signal right and sound your horn
Wait for the signal to be cancelled before overtaking

Text: You are on a narrow road at night. A slower-moving vehicle ahead has been signalling right for some time. What should you do?

Answers.Text: To pull into if the car behind wants to overtake
To turn the car around in  if you are lost
For stopping and checking your route
To pull into if an oncoming vehicle wants to proceed
For taking a rest from driving

Text: Which TWO are correct? The passing places on a narrow single- track road are:

Answers.Text: Put on your hazard warning lights
Reverse back to the main road

Text: You see a vehicle coming towards you on a narrow single-track road. You should:

Answers.Text: Position your vehicle in the centre lane

Text: As soon as you join a dual carriageway you should normally:

Answers.Text: Come to a stop before joining the dual carriageway
Stop at the end of the acceleration lane
Give way to traffic already on the dual carriageway

Text: When joining a dual carriageway you must always:

Answers.Text: Try to keep above 50 kph to prevent congestion
Keep to the left lane unless overtaking
Overtake on the side that is clearest
Use the lane that has least traffic

Text: A fundamental rule when driving on a dual carriageway is:

Answers.Text: There is a police speed check up ahead
The other car is going to change lanes
Traffic ahead is slowing or stopping suddenly
The driver wants you to overtake

Text: You are driving on a dual carriageway and the car ahead shows its hazard lights for a short time. This tells you that:
You are driving on a dual carriageway. You have to slow down quickly due to a hazard. You should:
Which vehicles are normally fitted with amber flashing beacons on the roof?
What should you use the hard shoulder of a multi-lane- carriageway for?

Answers.Text: Wait on the hard shoulder until someone flashes their
Move out onto the carriageway using your hazard lights
Gain speed on the hard shoulder before moving out onto the carriageway
Move out onto the carriageway then build up your speed

Text: After a breakdown you need to rejoin the main carriageway of a multi-lane-carriageway from the hard shoulder. You should:
The minimum safe time gap to keep between you and the vehicle in front in good conditions is at least:

You are intending to leave the multi-lane-carriageway at the next exit. Before you reach the exit you should normally position your
vehicle:

Answers.Text: Make a U-turn at the next gap in the central reservation
Carry on to the next exit
Carefully reverse in the left-hand lane
Carefully reverse on the hard shoulder

Text: You are driving on a multi-lane- carriageway. By mistake, you go past the exit that you wanted to take. You should:

Answers.Text: When the pavement is very wide
To gain lawful access into a property

Text: You may drive over a footpath:
What is the national speed limit outside built up areas unless otherwise indicated  for cars and motorcycles?
What is the national speed limit unless otherwise indicated  on dual carriageways for cars and motorcycles?

Answers.Text: Children may run out from between the vehicles
You may set off car alarms
So that oncoming traffic can see you more clearly

Text: You are driving along a street with parked vehicles on the left-hand side. For which THREE reasons should you keep your speed down?

Answers.Text: Drive on; it is your right of way

Text: You meet an obstruction on your side of the road. You should:

Answers.Text: Speed through but flash your lights to oncoming traffic
Sound your horn to the slow vehicle to pull over
Not overtake if you are in doubt

Text: There is a tractor ahead of you. You wish to overtake but you are NOT sure if it is safe to do so. You should:
Which three of the following are most likely to take an unusual course at roundabouts?

Answers.Text: If you will be parked for less than five minutes

Text: You are leaving your vehicle parked on a road. When may you leave the engine running?

Answers.Text: On the slope of a hill
On the brow of a hill
In front of someone else's drive-way/garage

Text: In which Five places must you NOT park or wait?
What is the nearest you may park your vehicle to a junction?

Answers.Text: Yes  if you don't block people from crossing
Yes  in order to drop off a passenger
No  unless you stay with your car

Text:
You are finding it difficult to find a parking place in a busy town. You can see there is space on the zigzag lines of a zebra crossing. Can you
park there?
In which TWO places must you NOT park?

Answers.Text: Use these spaces  disabled or not
Park if you stay with your vehicle
Use these spaces when elsewhere is full

Text: You are looking for somewhere to park your vehicle. The area is full EXCEPT for spaces marked 'disabled use'. You can:

Answers.Text: Only if the other driver dips his headlights
Before the vehicles starts to pass you
Some time after the vehicles has passed you
As soon as the vehicle passes you

Text: You are driving at night with full- beam headlights on. A vehicle is overtaking you. You should dip your lights:

Answers.Text: Driving at the minimum allowed speed

Text: You are driving on a two-lane carriageway. For which TWO of the following would you use the right- hand lane?

Answers.Text: Obey the limit except for overnight
Accept the speed limit as advisable
Obey the limit only during rush hour

Text: You are entering an area of roadworks. There is a temporary speed limit displayed. You must:

Answers.Text: Use clear arm signals to cut across
Stop until the area has cleared

Text:
You are approaching a busy junction. There are several lanes with road markings. At the last moment you realise that you are in
the wrong lane. You should:

Answers.Text: Either on the right or the left

Text: Where may you overtake on a one- way street?

Answers.Text: Drive into a passing place on your right
Switch on your hazard warning lights
Wait opposite a passing place on your right
Speed up to get away from the following driver

Text: You are going along a single-track road with passing places only on the right. The driver behind wishes to overtake. You should:

Answers.Text: Wait opposite a passing place on your left
Pull into a passing place if your vehicle is wider
Force the other driver to reverse
Wait opposite a passing place on your right
Pull into a passing place on your left
Pull into a passing place on your right

Text: You are on a road that is only wide enough for one vehicle. There is a car coming towards you. Which TWO of these would be correct?
Signals are normally given by direction indicators and:

Answers.Text: Indicate left just after you pass the exit before the one you will take
Indicate left when approaching the roundabout
Indicate right when approaching the roundabout

Text: When going straight ahead at a roundabout you should:
Which vehicle might have to use a different course than normal at roundabouts?

Answers.Text: Signal right on the approach and then left to leave the
Signal left on the approach to the roundabout and keep the signal on until you leave
Signal left as you leave the roundabouts
Signal left just after you pass the exit before the one you will take

Text: You are going straight ahead at a roundabout. How should you signal?

Answers.Text: The vehicle on the widest road

Text: At a crossroads there are no signs or road markings. Two vehicles approach. Which has priority?

Answers.Text: The driver on the wider road
The driver who is going faster
The driver of the larger vehicle

Text: Who has priority at an unmarked crossroads?

Answers.Text: Keep the other vehicle to your RIGHT and turn behind it (offside to offside)
Hold back, wait for the other driver to turn first
Carry on and turn at the next junction instead
Keep the other vehicle to your LEFT and turn in front of it (nearside to nearside)

Text: You are intending to turn right at a junction. An oncoming driver is also turning right. It will normally be safer to:

Answers.Text: Emerge slightly to show your intentions
Wait until the road is clear in both directions
Stop in the first lane so that other vehicles give way
Proceed to central reservation and wait

Text: The dual carriageway you are turning right onto has a narrow central reservation. You should:

Answers.Text: Swing out wide just before turning
Keep in the middle of the road
Keep just left of the middle of the road
Keep well to the left of the road

Text: While driving  you intend to turn left into a minor road. On the approach you should:

Answers.Text: There are less than two vehicles in front of you

Text: You may only enter a box junction when:

Answers.Text: Ignore them as they are still on the pavement
Stop before you reach the zigzag lines and let them cross
Stop, let them cross and wait patiently
Go on quickly before they step onto the crossing

Text: Someone is waiting to cross at a zebra crossing. They are standing on the pavement. You should normally:

Answers.Text: Make a 'three point' turn in the main road
Make a U-turn in the main road
Turn into a side road on the road on the right and reverse into the main road.
Turn round in a side road

Text: You are on a busy main road and find that you are in a wrong direction. What should you do?

Answers.Text: Find a quiet side road to turn round in
Get someone to stop the traffic
Drive into a side road and reverse into the main road

Text: You are parked in a busy high street. What is the safest way to turn your vehicle around to go the opposite way?

Answers.Text: So that you are on the correct side of the road before and after turning left or right at junctions and when approaching roundabouts
So that you are always in the correct lane on a multi-lane road.
Staying in the lane of your choice as long as you are driving within the speed limit.
So that nobody can overtake you if they are speeding.

Text: Why is it important for you to maintain road position.

Answers.Text: No lights are necessary as tunnels have their own lighting.
Dipped-beam to help you see and also be clearly seen by others.
Hazard warning lights so nobody drives too near.
Main-beam to see clearly where you are going.

Text: What lights should you use and why, when going through a tunnel?

Answers.Text: On the outside lane if the vehicle in front of you on the inner lane is not going fast enough.
On the inside lane if the vehicle in front of me on the outside lane is not going fast enough.
Never under normal circumstances as overtaking in tunnels is prohibited.
If a broken down vehicle or other static hazard is obstructing the lane you are driving in, after having checked and signaled correctly

Text: When can you overtake in a tunnel?
What are the maximum national speed limits for cars and motorcycles in built-up areas and elsewhere?
You MUST obey signs giving orders. These signs are mostly in:

Answers.Text: Give way to traffic from the right
Give way to traffic from the other way
Give way to traffic from the left

Text: At a mini-roundabout you should:

Answers.Text: Give directions to a car park
Give warning of a motorway ahead

Text: What does a circular traffic sign with a blue background do?
What does a sign with a brown background show?
What are triangular signs for?
Which FOUR of these would be indicated by a triangular road sign?
You are approaching a red traffic light. The signal will change from red to:

Answers.Text: Stop  if you are able to brake safely
You must stop and wait behind the stop line
You should stop unless turning left

Text: A red traffic light means:

Answers.Text: Go if no pedestrians are crossing
Go if the way is clear
Prepare to stop at the stop line

Text: At traffic lights  amber on its own means:

Answers.Text: You must stop behind the white stop line
You must slow down and prepare to stop if traffic has started to cross
You may turn left if it is safe to do so
You may drive straight on if there is no other traffic

Text: A red traffic light means:

Answers.Text: The lights are about to change to red
There is a fault with the lights - take care
Wait for the green light before you pass the lights
Pass the lights if the road is clear

Text: You are approaching traffic lights. Red and amber are showing. This means:

Answers.Text: When you intend to turn right
When your intended route from the junction is blocked
When you think the lights may be about to change
When pedestrians are waiting to cross

Text: You are at a junction controlled by traffic lights. When should you NOT proceed at green?

Answers.Text: Sounding of horns is not allowed
Parking allowed only for a short time

Text: What do these zigzag lines at pedestrian crossings mean?

Answers.Text: Position over the centre line at an angle
Give an arm signal as well as an indicator signal

Text: You are to turn right in busy traffic. How would you confirm your intention safely?

Answers.Text: Keep well over to the right
Get out and check if your indicators can be seen
Give an arm signal as well as an indicator signal

Text: You want to turn right at a junction but you think that your indicators cannot be seen clearly. What should you do?

Answers.Text: To avoid damage to the indicator relay
To avoid misleading other road users
To avoid dazzling other road users

Text: Why should you make sure that you have cancelled your indicators after turning?

Answers.Text: Wait until the vehicle starts to turn in
Pull out before the vehicle reaches the junction

Text: You are waiting at a T-junction. A vehicle is coming from the right with the left signalflashing. What should you do?
What is the maximum speed limit in a built up area unless indicated otherwise?

Answers.Text: Have held a full licence for at least 5 years

Text: To supervise a learner driver you must:

Answers.Text: When you are taxing your vehicle
When a police officer asks you for it
When buying or selling a vehicle

Text: For which THREE of these must you show your motor insurance certificate?

Answers.Text: The owner has left the insurance documents in the vehicle
Your own vehicle has insurance cover
The vehicle is also insured for your use
The vehicle owner has third party insurance cover

Text: Before driving anyone else's motor vehicle you should make sure that:
What is the legal minimum insurance cover you must have to drive on public roads?

Answers.Text: A valid road tax disc displayed on your vehicle

Text: Which THREE of the following do you need before you can drive legally?
Which TWO pieces of information are found on a vehicle registration document?

Answers.Text: 4 points a year over a 3 year period.
12 points at any time during a 3 year period.
18 points over a two year period.
10 points during any one year period.
15 points over a five 5 year period.

Text: What is the maximum number of penalty points that will automatically disqualify a driver who holds a probationary driving licence?

Answers.Text: Simply re-sit and pass the test of skills and behaviour.
Re-apply as for a new driver after expiry of disqualification period and must re-sit and pass the theory test
Pay any outstanding fines  submit a new licence application after expiry of disqualification period and re-sit and pass both the theory and practical tests
Wait for any disqualification period to pass and apply for a duplicate driving licence.

Text: Apart from complying with any punishment according to law  what will a disqualified driver have to do to obtain a driving licence?
Who is responsible for ensuring that a vehicle is fully road worthy when driven on a public road?

Answers.Text: Pull everybody out of their vehicles
Go to those casualties who are screaming

Text: At the scene of an accident you should:

Answers.Text: Move uninjured people away from the vehicle(s)
Leave as soon as another motorist arrives

Text: You are the first to arrive at the scene of an accident. Which FOUR of these should you do?

Answers.Text: Move the people who are injured clear of their vehicles
Try and get people who are injured to drink something
Get people who are not injured clear of the scene
Make sure that someone telephones for an ambulance
Switch on your own hazard warning lights

Text: You are the first person to arrive at an accident where people are badly injured. Which THREE should you do?

Answers.Text: Always  unless they are in shock

Text: You arrive at the scene of a motorcycle accident. The rider is injured. When should the helmet be removed?

Answers.Text: Take the numbers of the vehicles involved
Check that the airway is clear

Text: You arrive at a serious motorcycle accident. The motorcyclist is unconscious and bleeding. Your main priorities should be to:
You arrive at an accident. A motorcyclist is unconscious. Your FIRST priority is the casualty's
At an accident a casualty is unconscious. Which THREE of the following should you check urgently?
In first aid what does ABC stand for?

Answers.Text: Check that the airway is clear
Count the number of vehicles involved

Text: At an accident someone is unconscious. Your main priorities should be to:
There has been an accident. The driver is suffering from shock. You should:
You are at the scene of an accident. Someone is suffering from shock. You should:

Answers.Text: Move the rider out of the road

Text: You arrive at the scene of a motorcycle accident. No other vehicle is involved. The rider is unconscious  lying in the middle of the road. The first thing you should do is:
At an accident a small child is not breathing. When giving a mouth to mouth you should breathe

Answers.Text: Put their arms across their chest

Text: To start mouth to mouth on a casualty you should:

Answers.Text: Douse the burn thoroughly with cold water

Text: You arrive at the scene of an accident and a casualty is suffering from severe burns. You should:

Answers.Text: Remove anything stuck to the burns
Douse the burns with cold water

Text: You arrive at an accident where someone is suffering from severe burns. You should:

Answers.Text: Raise the leg to lessen bleeding
Apply firm pressure to the wound to stop bleeding
Keep both legs flat on the ground
Dab the wound to stop bleeding

Text: You arrive at the scene of an accident. A pedestrian has a severe bleeding wound on the leg although it is not broken. What should you do?

Answers.Text: Apply pressure over the wound and keep the arm down
Apply pressure over the wound and raise the arm

Text: You arrive at a scene of an accident. A passenger is bleeding badly from an arm wound. What should you do?

Answers.Text: There is further danger to the casualty
An ambulance is on its way

Text: At an accident a casualty is unconscious but still breathing. You should only move the person if :
At an accident you suspect that a casualty has back injuries. The area is safe. You should:
The police may ask you to produce which three of these documents following an accident?

Answers.Text: For a short rest when tired

Text: On the dual carriageway the hard shoulder should be used
Overloading your vehicle can seriously affect the :

Answers.Text: The person who loaded the vehicle
The owner of the items being carried

Text: Who is responsible for making sure that a vehicle is not overloaded?
What is the meaning of this sign?

Answers.Text: The minimum speed limit ahead is 30 kph
You are leaving the 30 kph speed limit area
Start to slow down to 30 kph after passing it
Do not exceed 30 kph after passing it

Text: You see this sign ahead of you. It means:

Answers.Text: The speed shown allows for various road and weather conditions
The speed shown is the advised maximum
It is safe to drive at the speed shown
You must not exceed the speed shown

Text: What does a speed limit sign like this mean?
What is the meaning of this sign?
Traffic signs giving orders are generally which shape?
Which type of sign tells you NOT to do something?

Answers.Text: Maximum speed limit with traffic calming measures
Only 20 cars allowed at any one time
Minimum speed limit with traffic calming measures

Text: What does this sign mean?
Which sign means no motor vehicles are allowed?
Which of these signs means no motor vehicles?
What does this sign mean?
What does this sign mean?
What does this sign mean?
What does this sign mean?
Which sign means 'no entry'?
What does this sign mean?
What does this sign mean?
What does this sign mean?
Which sign means 'no stopping'?
What does this sign mean?
You see this sign ahead. It means:
What does this traffic sign mean?

Answers.Text: Give priority to vehicles coming towards you
You have priority over vehicles coming towards you

Text: What is the meaning of this traffic sign?
Which sign means 'traffic has priority over oncoming vehicles'?

Answers.Text: Stop  ONLY if a red light is showing
Stop  ONLY if children are waiting to cross
Stop  ONLY if traffic is approaching
Stop  even if the road is clear

Text: What MUST you do when you see this sign?

Answers.Text: You are entering a one-way street
You have priority over vehicles from the opposite direction

Text: What does this sign mean?
What shape is a STOP sign at a junction?
Which shape is used for GIVE WAY sign?

Answers.Text: Turn off at the next available junction
Approaching traffic passes you on both sides
Pass either side to get to the same destination

Text: What does this sign mean?
What does this sign means?
What does this sign mean?
What does this sign mean?
Which sign means that pedestrians may be walking together along the road?
Which of these signs warn you of a pedestrian crossing?
What does this sign mean?
What does this sign mean?
Which of these signs means there is a double bend ahead?
What does this sign mean?
What does this sign mean?
Which of these signs means the end of a dual carriageway?
What does this sign mean?

Answers.Text: Two-way traffic ahead across a one-way street

Text: What does this sign mean?
What does this traffic sign mean?

Answers.Text: Switch your headlights on before overtaking
Move to the right to get a better view
Overtake the other driver as quickly as possible
Hold back until you can see clearly ahead

Text: You are about to overtake when you see this sign. You should:
What does this sign mean?
What does this sign mean?

Answers.Text: No through road on the left
No entry for traffic turning left

Text: What does this sign mean?
What does this sign mean?
Which sign means 'no through road'?
Which of the following signs informs you that you are coming to a No Through Road?

Answers.Text: The right-hand lane ahead is narrow
Right hand lane for turning right
The right-hand lane ahead is closed

Text: What does this sign mean?
You see this traffic light ahead. Which light(s) will come on next?
This marking appears on the road just before a

Answers.Text: Give way to traffic from the right
Traffic from the left has right of way

Text:
You see this line across the road at the entrance to a roundabout.
What does it mean?

Answers.Text: The driver intends to turn right
The drivers intends to turn left

Text: The driver of the car in front is giving this signal. What does it mean?
The driver of this car is giving an arm signal. What is he about to do?
Which of these signs means that the national speed limit applies?

Answers.Text: Hatched traffic stream separator warning lines that may be used for overtaking as long as no traffic is coming from the opposite direction
Central reservation and can be used for overtaking if no traffic is coming from the opposite direction.

Hatching bordered by continuous solid white lines intended to separate two opposing streams of traffic  which lines must not be crossed or entered into except in an emergency or when directed to do so by the police

Text: Which of the following describe these road markings?
The white arrow in the diagram means that you should not plan to :

Answers.Text: Drivers that it is safe to overtake
Overtaking drivers there is a bend to the left
Overtaking drivers to move back to the left
Drivers to use the hard shoulder

Text: The road marking in the diagram warns :
You see this sign ahead. You should expect the road to:
Objects or articles hanging from your interior mirror may :

Answers.Text: Switch on the heated rear window

Text: When driving you are most likely to lose concentration if you :
When driving  which four are most likely to cause you to lose concentration

Answers.Text: Keep both hands on the wheel
Apply the handbrake and footbrake together

Text: You are driving on a wet road and you have to stop your vehicle in an emergency. You should:

Answers.Text: Putting in a cassette tape/ CD
Pulling up to tune the radio

Text: Which of the following may cause distraction on a long journey?

Answers.Text: After stopping in a suitable place
If you feel your driving will be unaffected
If you are driving on a motorway
When driving on a quiet  minor roads

Text: You want to use a mobile phone whilst driving the car. You should only use the phone:

Answers.Text: Direct your call through the operator
Find a suitable place to stop
Drive slowly on a quiet road

Text: What is the safest way to use a mobile phone in a car?
You are driving on a clear night. There is a steady stream of oncoming cars. The national speed limit applies. Which lights should you use?

Answers.Text: Use both the handbrake and footbrake

Text: You are waiting in a traffic queue at night. To avoid dazzling the drivers behind you should:

Answers.Text: Give a left signal when it is safe for vehicles to overtake you
Wave following vehicles past you if you think they can overtake quickly
Pull in safely when you can to let following vehicles overtake
Keep well out to stop vehicles overtaking dangerously

Text: You are driving a slow-moving car on a narrow winding road. You should :

Answers.Text: Stop immediately and wave it on
Put your hazard warning lights on
Pull in safely as soon as you can do so

Text: You are driving a slow-moving car on a narrow road. When traffic wishes to overtake you should :

Answers.Text: Keep left and hold your speed
Pull in safely when you can

Text: You are driving a slow-moving car on a narrow winding road. In order to let other vehicles overtake, you should :
Which of the following are at greatest risk from other road users?
Which FOUR of these MUST be in good working order for your car to be safe and roadworthy?

Answers.Text: Allow the exhaust system to be recycled
Prolong the life of the exhaust system

Text: New petrol-engined cars have to be fitted with catalytic converters. The reason for this is to:
What can cause heavy or difficult steering?
Your car is fitted with power assisted steering. This will make the steering seem:
A police officer orders you to stop and finds you have a faulty tyre. Who is responsible for the tyre?
The legal minimum depth of tread for car tyres over three quarters of its breadth is:
Excessive or uneven wear in one or more tyres can be caused by faults in the:
There is vibration on your steering wheel as you drive at certain speeds. You should check that the:

Answers.Text: Use your handbrake at the same time
Have the fault checked by a competent mechanic as soon as possible
Pump the pedal when braking and steer in opposite direction

Text: Your vehicle pulls to one side when braking heavily. You should:
The main cause of brake pedal fade is:

Answers.Text: Check that the handbrake is released

Text: Your anti-lock brakes warning light stays on. You should:

Answers.Text: To park on double yellows lines
When you have broken down in traffic

Text: When may you use hazard lights?

Answers.Text: Broken down and causing an obstruction

Text: Hazard lights should be used when vehicles are:

Answers.Text: Help you to maintain your driving position
Help you to avoid neck injury

Text: A properly adjusted head rest will:
What will reduce the risk of neck injury resulting from a car collision?

Answers.Text: Not over-revving in the lower gears
Making sure your tyres are correctly inflated
Keeping an empty roof rack properly fitted
Driving at higher speeds where possible

Text: To reduce harming  the environment  you can avoid wasting fuel by:

Answers.Text: To make sure diesel and petrol engines emit the same fumes
To help protect the environment against pollution
To discover which fuel supplier is used the most
To recover the cost of expensive garage equipment

Text: Why do VRT tests include an exhaust emission test?

You are testing the suspension of your car. You notice that your vehicle keeps bouncing when you press down on the front wing.
What does this mean?

Answers.Text: Using the wrong grade of fuel

Text: Which THREE of the following are most likely to increase fuel consumption?

Answers.Text: Cause diesel to spill and make roads slippery for others road users
Increase the level of exhaust emissions

Text: The filler cap on your diesel fuel tank is loose. This will:
Care should be taken when refueling with diesel  because when spilt it is:

Answers.Text: Open the door and look behind
Open your window to look behind

Text: If you cannot see clearly behind when reversing  what should you do?

Answers.Text: You a refund on your road tax

Text: A properly serviced car will give:
When a roof rack is not in use it should be removed. Why?
A roof rack that is fitted to your car will:

Answers.Text: Walk or cycle on short journeys
Use a car with a smaller engine
Travel by car at all times

Text: To reduce the volume of cars on the roads you could:

Answers.Text: When your vehicle has broken down and is causing an obstruction
When warning oncoming traffic that you intend to stop
When your direction indicators are not working
When you are double parked on a two-way road
When slowing down to warn other drivers behind of a hazard ahead

Text: For which TWO of these should you use hazard-warning lights?
If daytime visibility is poor but not seriously reduced  you should switch on:

Answers.Text: Apply the handbrake to reduce the stopping distance
Press the brake pedal rapidly and firmly until you have stopped
Keep pushing and releasing the foot brake quickly to prevent skidding
Brake normally and avoid turning the steering wheel

Text: If your car is fitted with anti-lock brakes and you need to stop in an emergency. You should:
Anti-lock brakes reduce the chances of a skid occurring particularly when:

Answers.Text: Are not fitted with a handbrake
Can be steered while you are braking

Text: Vehicles fitted with an anti-lock brake system:
Anti-lock brakes may not work as effectively as you expect if the road surface is:
What is the MOSTcommon reason a car skids?
When braking hard in a straight line most of the weight of the vehicle will shift onto the:
You have driven your car through a flood. What is the first thing you should do?

Answers.Text: Brake firmly and steer to the left
Brake firmly and not turn the steering wheel

Text: You are turning left on a slippery road. The back of your vehicle slides to the right. You should:

Answers.Text: Push harder on the brake pedal

Text: Your vehicle does not have anti- lock brakes.  If you are braking on a wet road and your vehicle begins to skid. What is the FIRST thing you should do?
Clutch Coasting will :

Answers.Text: Select a low gear and avoid using the brakes
Select a high gear and use the brakes firmly
Select a high gear and use the brakes carefully
Select a low gear and use the brakes carefully

Text: You are about to go down a steep hill. To control the speed of your car you should:
You are on a long  downhill slope. What should you do to help control the speed of your car?

Answers.Text: Turn the steering wheel towards the kerb
Turn the steering wheel away from the kerb
Park with two wheels on the kerb
Park close to the bumper of another car

Text: You wish to park facing DOWNHILL. Which TWO of the following should you do?

Answers.Text: When it is raining and just in case the roads are slippery.
When the road is unlit by street lamps or they are not working.
During any time of the day or night to make sure that other road users see me.
When visibility is considerably reduced because of fog.

Text: When should you use front and rear fog lights?

Answers.Text: Rest your hand on the gear lever
Have a suitable grip on the steering wheel
Have good visibility through the windows
Rest your head against the head restraint

Text: A correct seating position will enable you to:

Answers.Text: Carry on assuming it is clear
Look through the rear window only

Text: You want to reverse into a side road. You are not sure that the area behind your car is clear. What should you do?

Answers.Text: Reverse before the pedestrian starts to cross
Wave to the pedestrian to cross
Wave to the pedestrian to stop

Text: You are about to reverse into a side road and a pedestrian wishes to cross behind you. You should:
Who is especially in danger of not being seen as you reverse your car?
You intend to turn right into a side road. Just before turning you should check for motorcyclists who may be:

Answers.Text: At or near a bus stop
Where the kerb has been lowered for wheelchairs
Near the brow of a hill

Text: In which three places would parking cause an obstruction to other road users?

Answers.Text: Stop and wave them across the road
Speed up to get past them quickly
Expect them to wait for you to pass
Be careful  they may misjudge your speed

Text: You are following a motorcyclist on an uneven and bumpy road. You should:

Answers.Text: Allow the same room as normal because motorcyclists are not
Allow extra room in case they swerve to avoid pot-holes
Allow less room to ensure that you can be seen in their mirrors

Text: You are following a motorcyclist on an uneven road. You should:
Which TWO should you allow extra room when overtaking?

Answers.Text: The rider may be traveling faster than normal
The rider may be blown across in front of you
The rider may turn off suddenly to get out of the wind

Text: Why should you allow extra room when overtaking a motorcyclist on a windy day?
Which type of vehicle is MOST affected by strong winds?

Answers.Text: They might not see you turn
They may slow down to let you turn
They may want to turn into the side road

Text: Why should you particularly look for motorcyclists and cyclists at any junction?

Answers.Text: Motorcycles are small and hard to see
Motorcycles are usually faster than cars

Text: You are waiting to come out of a side road. Why should you watch carefully for motorcycles?

Answers.Text: Looking around helps them balance as they turn
They need to listen for following traffic
They need to check for traffic in their blind area

Text: Motorcyclists often look round over their right shoulder just before turning right. This is because:

Answers.Text: Passing very close to your car
Riding with their headlamp on dipped beam
Cutting in just in front of you

Text: Which of the following are hazards that motorcyclists present in queues of traffic?

Answers.Text: Look for motorcyclists filtering through the traffic

Text: You are driving in slow-moving queues of traffic. Just before changing lane you should:

Answers.Text: Stop at the scene of the accident
Stop only if there are injured people

Text: You have a collision while your car is moving. What is the first important thing you must do?

Answers.Text: Be over 25 and have held a full licence for at least 5 years
Be over 21 and have had a full license for at least three years.
Be over 18 and have fully comprehensive insurance
Be over 18 and hold an advanced driver's certificate

Text: If a friend wants to teach you how to drive a car  they must:
Your car hits a pedestrian at 60 kph. The pedestrian will:

Answers.Text: Switch your rear lights on and off
Set your mirror to dazzle the other driver

Text: You are dazzled at night by the lights of the vehicle behind you. You should:

Answers.Text: To avoid splashing pedestrians on the pavements
To help judge the bend using the drain covers as marker points
To avoid puncturing the tyres on the edge of the drain covers
To prevent the motorcycle sliding on the metal drain covers

Text: The road is wet and slippery. Why might a motorcyclist steer round drain covers on a bend?
It is very windy. You are behind a motorcyclist who is overtaking a high vehicle. What should you do?
It is very blustery and windy. You are about to overtake a motorcyclist. You should:
You should avoid 'coasting' your car because it could:

You are driving in the left-hand lane of a dual carriageway. Another car overtakes and pulls in front of you leaving you without enough
separation distance. You should:

Answers.Text: Are always faster than other drivers
Are more likely to break down than other motorists
Are less experienced that other drivers
Are more difficult to see than other drivers

Text: Motorcyclists are more at risk to be injured from other road users because they:
To correct a rear-wheel skid you should:
You are driving in very wet weather. Your vehicle begins to slide. This affect is called:

Answers.Text: Top up the radiator with antifreeze
Check that your lights are working
Make sure that the windows are clean
Make sure that you have a warning triangle in the vehicle

Text: You have to make a journey in fog. What are the TWO most important things you should do before you set out?

Answers.Text: An audible warning device is used
They are not as bright as the headlights
They are fitted above the bumper

Text: Front fog lights may be used ONLY if:

Answers.Text: If they are not as bright as the headlights

Text: Front fog lights may be used ONLY if:

Answers.Text: They were fitted by the vehicle manufacturer
They are operated with rear fog lights

Text: Front fog lights may be used ONLY if:

Answers.Text: You wish to overtake in bad weather
They prevent headlights glare on a wet road

Text: Front fog lights may be used ONLY if:
Fog lights should be used ONLY when:
Using front/rear fog lights in good visibility will:

Answers.Text: Help your indicators to be seen more clearly
Make other drivers think you are braking
Give a better view of the road ahead
Reduce glare from the road surface

Text: You are driving on a clear dry night with your rear fog lights switched on. This may:

Answers.Text: Direction indicators may not work properly

Text: Why is it dangerous to leave rear fog lights on when they are not needed?
You are driving in thick fog using fog lights. When visibility improves you MUST:

Answers.Text: Used outside built up areas only
Connected to an audible warning signal
Switched off if visibility is not seriously reduced

Text: Front and rear fog lights MUST be:

Answers.Text: Both hands on the steering wheel at all times and only when a change of gear or operation of controls is necessary
One hand on the steering wheel and the other simply hanging out of the window to catch the breeze and look cool
One hand on the steering wheel and the other being used to hold a mobile phone.
One hand on the steering wheel and the other grasping the gear lever for the most part to facilitate instant gear changing

Text: Which statement represents being in safe control of your vehicle?
You may remove your seat belt temporarily when carrying out a manoeuvre that involves:

Answers.Text: For more than a car's length

Text: You must not reverse:
When you are NOT sure that it is safe to reverse your vehicle you should:

Answers.Text: After you've entered the side road
Just before you actually begin to manoeuvre
When the front of your vehicle swings out

Text: You are reversing your vehicle into a side road. When would the greatest hazard to passing traffic occur?

Answers.Text: Damage to your car by fire

Text: Your car has third party insurance. What does this cover?

Answers.Text: One year after the date it was issued
Two years after the date it was issued

Text: A VRT certificate is normally valid for:

Answers.Text: Ask drivers to switch off their engines
Offer someone a cigarette to calm them down
Warn other traffic by switching on your hazard warning lights

Text: Which of the following should you NOT do at the scene of an accident?

Answers.Text: When you slow down quickly because of a hazard ahead
When you need to park on the pavement
When you wish to stop on double yellow lines

Text: For which TWO should you use hazard-warning lights?

Answers.Text: When you cannot avoid causing an obstruction
When you are parked on double yellow lines
When you are towing a broken down vehicle
When you are driving slowly due to bad weather

Text: When should you switch on your hazard warning lights?

Answers.Text: Continue on at a normal speed
Hold the steering wheel firmly to keep control
Pull up slowly at the side of the road

Text: Your tyre bursts while you are driving. Which TWO things should you do?

Answers.Text: Let the vehicle roll to a stop
Stop gradually at the side of the road
Apply the handbrake to stop the vehicle

Text: Which TWO things should you do when a front tyre bursts?
Any load that is carried on a roof rack MUST be:
A heavy load on your roof rack will MAINLY:
